content: @DPC I think proposed continuing our conversation about minutes here, @Santiago Pastorino
I do tend to argee it'd be great to have a "note-taker" assigned ahead of time
but I also feel like...as I said...it's kind of hard to do it
one thing I've thought about is having a pool of folks who are game to do that
and just assigning them round-robin to the meetings
I guess this ties in to a more general concept I've been floating of having "roles" within the compiler team
which I've never really had time to enumerate
but the idea would be to have some set of people that play the role of "meeting manager(s)" for a term, say 6 months
along with other roles, such as mentoring newcomers, or tending PR queue, prioritization, idk .. probably up to and including lead
had a strange idea - what if people could react with a specfic reaction (such as :note: ) to important points being discussed and those could be aggregated into a list of notes :grinning:
@nikomatsakis have you considered to have as note taker the person that proposed the meeting?
not sure if there's always someone that proposed the meeting
and even if that's a fair thing to do
or even if that would make people abstain from even proposing something to avoid note taking :joy:

nikomatsakis said:

one thing I've thought about is having a pool of folks who are game to do that

If this is the approach that's chosen, I just wanted to propose to help, the only issue that I have is that I could be "unreliable" (i.e. I can't really be sure I will be available at a given date to take notes). Maybe I could be part of a bench pool? :D
I can volunteer as well, just have the same problem as @LeSeulArtichaut and end up missing some of the meetings

Santiago Pastorino said:

nikomatsakis have you considered to have as note taker the person that proposed the meeting?

From the perspective of someone who's never been part of a design meeting, I'd think that maybe assigning the person that proposed the meeting could make them more busy in the meeting and "hurt" the flow of the meeting because they have to take notes when they could react to the current conversation.
yeah, but they may not take notes during the meeting, they may just revisit it at the end
I think taking notes during the meeting works if the person that does that is not the one that is running the meeting

Right, going through hundreds of messages is not especially fun but if that's assigned to the person who proposed the design, that seems fair to me; though I think it would probably be more optimal (I mean, less time-consuming overall) to have someone take notes during the meeting
Also, trying different things might make sense, I guess. Trial and error!
posit: have that person be _responsible for delegating_ if no other established solution is in place?
@Santiago Pastorino I have many times tried to find people to take notes
the problem is that fequently we don't get anyone volunteering
and it's not obvious what to do in that situation :)
but I think it's a good idea
as for emojis, we typically use :point_up: to signal "key point"
but I find when creating minutes that just scanning for any emojis is often quite useful
yeah, we can try to encourage everyone to provide "key points" to make the notes taking simpler

nikomatsakis said:

but I think it's a good idea

which one in particular?
I think it's a good idea to line up someone to take minutes
I've just found it hard in practice
